channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: Amazon has quietly stopped letting customers in Russia and Belarus open new cloud computing accounts. The policy change for Amazon Web Services started over the weekend, according to an internal communication viewed by The New York Times. https://t.co/ICTUx2J5h5
Cmdr. Billie J. Farrell was in sixth grade when she became interested in attending the U.S. Naval Academy. Today she is the first female commander of the U.S.S. Constitution. https://t.co/RWLxIvwJlt
One million children have fled Ukraine in less than two weeks of war, a spokesman for UNICEF said on Tuesday, calling it “a dark historical first.” https://t.co/jRwyIjeHS0 https://t.co/Gs2AWrE8Mq
Breaking News: Venezuela released two imprisoned Americans after talks with the U.S., a potential thaw in relations as Venezuela looks to resume oil trade. https://t.co/rGpujE9GFF
On International Women’s Day, these Ukrainian refugees were greeted by volunteers with flowers as they crossed the border into Romania. https://t.co/MnNIG6Qlhh https://t.co/IMHlu9BsUD

President Volodymyr Zelensky likened Ukraine’s struggle to that of Britain in the early days of World War II, when Nazi warplanes bombed London nightly, in a dramatic video speech to the British Parliament on Tuesday. https://t.co/RTgue4kU7r
McDonald’s, Starbucks and Coca-Cola will pause sales in Russia, after weeks of pressure to respond to the invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/2vVO1R8nCz

President Biden on Tuesday announced a ban on Russian oil and natural gas in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and warned that the action could result in higher prices for Americans at the gas pump. https://t.co/rRnckUSS0I https://t.co/lHlPLaUGFg

Russian restaurants in New York City are being hit by cancellations, social media campaigns and bad reviews online after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, despite most owners being openly antiwar and many coming from Ukraine. https://t.co/Kn0lSiybah
Breaking News: A Texas man who helped lead a mob against the police during the Jan. 6 attack was found guilty in the first criminal trial related to the riot. https://t.co/4r938o9T9X

The Kremlin is using state-controlled media to sanitize its war in Ukraine for a domestic audience. The destruction of cities and towns, the civilian deaths and the desperate exodus by millions of refugees are all missing from the coverage. https://t.co/TnW0qd9JWG https://t.co/7pBLiQEySr

Covid-19 shows no signs of going away. How do we live with the virus long term? The epidemiologist @BillHanage and the psychologist @DrSullivanATL join @apoorva_nyc to answer your questions. Join us now. https://t.co/jrHpxaCTM9 https://t.co/U75F8Q1soh
McDonald’s will temporarily close all its restaurants in Russia and pause operations there in response to the invasion of Ukraine, the company said on Tuesday. https://t.co/h9Ob24dZLq

President Biden is speaking now, announcing a ban on the importation of Russian oil and natural gas into the U.S. in response to its invasion of Ukraine.
Watch live: https://t.co/BXf1pKRZxB
Breaking News: Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys, has been charged with conspiracy in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. https://t.co/zL1LMUZKbr

The European Commission set out plans to “make Europe independent from Russian fossil fuels well before 2030.”
Europe relies on Russia for much of its oil and gas, but some fear Moscow could cut flows in response to the bloc’s support for Ukraine. https://t.co/rcMAcDwXtK https://t.co/pV0eB4JDd9
The Senate unanimously approved a bill to make lynching a federal hate crime, ending over a century of failed efforts to pass such a measure. https://t.co/FVViV3FQRo

Covid-19 shows no signs of going away. How do we live with the virus long term? The epidemiologist @BillHanage and the psychologist @DrSullivanATL join @apoorva_nyc today at 2:00 p.m. ET to answer your questions. DM them to @nytimesevents. https://t.co/F6rKNwSpkE

The New York Times is temporarily pulling its staff from Russia, the company said Tuesday, in the wake of a new law that effectively criminalizes independent reporting and puts journalists who describe the war as a war at risk of being sentenced to prison. https://t.co/tRd6tbeRLb

Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, will stop purchasing oil and gas from Russia and shut its service stations in the country, it said.
The move comes after Shell was criticized for buying discounted Russian crude. “We are sorry,” the company’s CEO said. https://t.co/6vXbWPwtAh

Russian restaurants in New York City are being hit by cancellations, social media campaigns and bad Yelp reviews after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, despite most owners being openly antiwar and many coming from Ukraine. https://t.co/vWzb6zq61q

Two million people have left Ukraine since the Russian invasion began, the UN refugee agency said. The total includes one million children, according to Unicef, whose spokesman called it “a dark historical first.”
Follow our updates. https://t.co/1ZAaGmpJ2Q https://t.co/MJCVrIeybt
Breaking News: President Biden is expected to ban the importation of Russian oil into the U.S., a senior official said. https://t.co/SDBmk9rsfh

President Volodymyr Zelensky has antagonized President Vladimir Putin through defiant videos and speeches since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
Why does he pose a unique threat to Putin? Listen to today's episode of The Daily. https://t.co/FjzFIb8Arr

Contradicting guidance from the CDC, Florida will soon recommend that healthy children not get vaccinated against Covid, the state’s surgeon general, Dr. Joseph Ladapo, announced on Monday. https://t.co/zxYxaWrtNG

Pixar has a reputation for films focused on and written by men. But its latest movie, "Turning Red," bucks that trend: an unabashedly female story directed by Domee Shi, the first woman in the studio's 36-year history to be in charge of a feature. https://t.co/7phlNX0YrL

Ukraine claimed on Tuesday to have shot down three Russian fighter jets and a cruise missile.
The assertion was backed up by several loud explosions over Kyiv, and is a sign that the country’s air defense systems and air force are still functioning. https://t.co/VZeSXPbMEX

Ukraine has shot down military transport planes carrying Russian paratroopers, downed helicopters and blown holes in Russia’s convoys using American anti-tank missiles and armed drones supplied by Turkey, U.S. officials said. https://t.co/COZ5US5bXK

Russia is trying to recruit Syrian fighters to join its forces in Ukraine, a sign that the Kremlin is frustrated with the pace and scope of operations in its invasion, a senior Pentagon official said on Monday. https://t.co/IB4Q3EUKsz

Switzerland broke with its tradition of neutrality when it imposed sanctions on Russia. But commodities trading has been allowed to continue — and the Swiss government estimates 80% of Russia's raw material and resources are traded in the country. https://t.co/56yV51z3gR

Publicly, Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin had vowed that the friendship between China and Russia had "no limits." Now it appears that Xi's display of solidarity may have, perhaps unwittingly, emboldened Putin to gamble on going to war. https://t.co/42iORPtnw2

The Paralympics are usually a time of celebration and camaraderie for athletes from Ukraine, which has one of the most successful teams per capita in the world. Now they wipe away tears, overwhelmed by worry about their loved ones, before competitions. https://t.co/dTBJ1wkFwL

The influx of Ukrainian refugees into Poland has prompted a grassroots movement across Polish society, as people raise funds and offer help. The warm welcome stands in stark contrast to how refugees from other countries have been received. https://t.co/BQiBEOJgsi https://t.co/q0WZHnUYTI

Indiscriminate Russian attacks have trapped and traumatized Ukrainians, magnifying a humanitarian crisis that has already left tens of thousands without food, water, power or heat. https://t.co/fIKTnfim2N https://t.co/a0c8MyVkPS

Oxana, holding her 3-year-old daughter in an emergency blanket, cries after fleeing Ukraine and crossing the border into Poland.
Follow live updates on the Ukraine war: https://t.co/s2LABvk5eK https://t.co/83U8LLWzyM
Covid may cause greater loss of gray matter and tissue damage in the brain than naturally occurs in people who have not been infected with the virus, a new study finds. https://t.co/n30OkOsIhQ

Russian troops hit residential neighborhoods in the Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv with a ferocious artillery attack on Monday, blowing out windows and sending shrapnel flying through walls. https://t.co/nvQtrMh0GT https://t.co/oSckZTWSDF

The "Z" first drew attention when it was painted on the sides of thousands of tanks and other military vehicles along the Russian border with Ukraine. Then the letter began popping up across Russia. https://t.co/v5iifdtelh
Breaking News: The Senate unanimously approved a bill to make lynching a federal hate crime, ending over a century of failed efforts to pass such a measure. https://t.co/Zso1W7dDSK

Ukraine has shot down military transport planes carrying Russian paratroopers, downed helicopters and blown holes in Russia’s convoys using American anti-tank missiles and armed drones supplied by Turkey, U.S. officials said. https://t.co/Ud8zr41muP

Breaking News: The Supreme Court on Monday allowed maps approved by state courts in North Carolina and Pennsylvania to stand, rejecting pleas from Republicans. State courts had ruled that earlier maps were warped by partisan gerrymandering. https://t.co/Si63B6XnMa

TikTok and Netflix are suspending their services. Twitter has been partially blocked. YouTube's future is in doubt. In Russia, a digital barricade has turned the country into a walled-off state akin to China and Iran. https://t.co/VJzxaKS5pU

Publicly, Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin had vowed that the friendship between China and Russia had "no limits." Now it appears that Xi's display of solidarity may have, perhaps unwittingly, emboldened Putin to gamble on going to war. https://t.co/Dd3eMjFM32

What are the books that changed your life? The writer @alexanderchee joins @heyitsfranklin2 and @lachristensen from @nytimesbooks to discuss the books that made them who they are. Join the live conversation on Thursday, March 10 at 1 p.m. ET. https://t.co/hDItJXV2p3

The German chancellor pushed back against the suggestion of imposing an embargo on oil and natural gas from Russia, admitting that his country is too dependent on Russian fossil fuels to survive cutting off supplies. https://t.co/acOSIimNjv
Covid may cause greater loss of gray matter and tissue damage in the brain than naturally occurs in people who have not been infected with the virus, a new study finds. https://t.co/XpgFcngEBX

Ukrainian jets and an antiaircraft missile shot down two Russian airplanes over Kyiv and in a nearby area, the commander of the Ukrainian military said in a statement on Monday. Western governments have said most of Ukraine's air force is intact. https://t.co/Q7Kd2zS84h

The average price of a gallon of gas in the U.S. reached $4 on Sunday, a 57-cent increase from a month ago, as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine disrupts the global energy market. The all-time high was in July 2008, when the average price hit $4.11. https://t.co/mIVIFvkXXB
Breaking News: The global Covid-19 death toll surpassed six million people. Public health experts say the true count will never be known. https://t.co/qfn0S6viCy https://t.co/TOx21X6h5k

The U.S. has sent 500 additional troops to Europe, a senior Pentagon official said Monday, bringing to more than 15,000 the number of troops the U.S. has sent in the run-up to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine on Feb. 24 and since then. https://t.co/tPWo7R4WBm
